description.plain:
British rock group Blur formed in 1988 and began life as a fairly unsuccessful shoegaze/madchester outfit, but the band quickly developed into becoming one of the leaders of the massive 1990s Britpop scene.

Their rivalry with contemporaries Oasis culminated in one of the most famous chart battles in British history – one which Blur won when “Country House” outsold Oasis’s “Roll With It” by 50,000 copies, giving Blur their first #1 single in the process.

Following this, the group embarked on a new musical direction, deliberately heading away from their trademark Britpop sound and instead taking influences from American alternative rock, a sound which earned them new fans in the US and gave them their second UK #1: “Beetlebum” in 1997.

However, due to rising tensions among the band members and the eventual departure of guitarist Graham Coxon, Blur went on a hiatus in 2003. Frontman Damon Albarn stayed in the music business both as a solo artist and with his cartoon band Gorillaz and supergroup The Good, the Bad and the Queen, and Coxon also continued making music. Meanwhile, Drummer Dave Rowntree went into politics, and bassist Alex James runs his own cheese farm.

Blur got back together in 2008 and toured, but fans had to wait until 2015 before their comeback-album The Magic Whip was released.

songs.title: “1” (Bill Laswell Session, 2000)

description.plain:
“1” was a demo recorded during the mysterious 2000 Bill Laswell sessions. The track shares many noticeable similarities with the style of Blur’s 1999 album 13, but also hints heavily to the “sound” of their 2003 album, Think Tank, the song devoid of the heavy feedback and most of the noise on 13, instead placing greater emphasis on melody and electronics, perhaps giving a hint to what Think Tank with Graham might have been like.

 Interestingly, a line from the song (“What’s the matter with me?”) is used in an alternate version of the Gorillaz song “Latin Simone”. However, it’s still unknown if “1” is directly related to the song or if “1” is even a demo of the song, aside from the line. That being said, it wouldn’t be the only time a Blur demo has been reworked into a Gorillaz song (Tomorrow Comes Today). Or a hidden track (Re-Hash), on the topic of Blur tracks becoming Gorillaz songs.

songs.title: “3” (Bill Laswell Session, 2000)

description.plain:
“3” was recorded during the 2000 Bill Laswell sessions. The song shares very noticeable similarities with the band’s 2003 album, Think Tank, more so than “1”, which was also recorded in that session.

Because of the repetitive distorted vocals vaguely reminiscent of “Crazy Beat” and the melody (in the same key as the aforementioned song), it is theorized “3” is a demo of that song. It should also be noted that there is a similarity in lyrics (the “yeah yeah” at the end of each line in the post-chorus), although a similarity this small is likely a  coincidence. A demo of “Crazy Beat” was also allegedly recorded with Bill Laswell. Additionally, although an official source has yet to be found, a lyric from an earlier version of “Crazy Beat” was supposedly “forget the rock”, which was later removed after the band was insisted by Norman Cook to do so.

On that same note, Damon Albarn had said about the early version of “Crazy Beat”,

The nearest thing I could compare it to is a really bad version of Daft Punk… It had this sort of mad vocoder-ish vocal and the melody was over a real sort of skanky groove and just this almost descending semi tonal guitar.

Which – let us be honest here – is a perfect descriptor for this song.

 Whether or not the song is, however, a drastically different demo of “Crazy Beat” is still up in the air. However, it certainly isn’t out of the realm of possibility.

songs.title: Avoid the Traffic

description.plain:
“Avoid the Traffic” is a bass-driven track, featuring chimes playing along with the drums. The track is an outtake from the Think Tank sessions.

 The track is almost entirely devoid of electronics, but features a heavily distorted voice popping in halfway through the song before disappearing for the rest of the one and a half minute song.

songs.title: Bang

description.plain:
“Bang” is a song by English band Blur, released on 29 July 1991 as the third single from their debut album Leisure.

It reached number 24 in the UK Singles Chart. Its disappointing performance relative to previous single “There’s No Other Way” marked the end of Blur’s initial period of popularity, which would not be equalled until the release of “Girls & Boys” three years later.

It has been all but disowned by the band, who claim it was written in less than 15 minutes in response to record company demands for another bankable single. It is almost never played live, and has not been included on either Blur: The Best Of or Midlife: A Beginner’s Guide to Blur. “I don’t think we’ll ever play that again”, Alex James remarked in 1999, having performed it during rehearsals for that year’s tour. “Fuckin' hell, worst verse you ever heard. Dannii Minogue gave it ‘Stinker of the Week’ in Number One.”

songs.title: Battle

description.plain:
The longest track on 13, “Battle” is also one of the most experimental tracks Blur has recorded. The lyrics are extremely cryptic, but given the album’s ‘breakup’ mood, one could assume the word ‘battle’ refers to the struggles of a failing relationship.

It features a syncopated drum beat, an almost amorphous bassline, and guitars that rarely sound like guitars. This gives the track an unique atmosphere of melancholy despair.

songs.title: Beagle 2

description.plain:
“Beagle 2” is an entirely instrumental track, released as a b-side to “No Distance Left to Run”, and was conceived around the time of Parklife.

 The track’s title became the callsign for a British lander that was sent to Mars, launched in 2003. The first 9 notes of “Beagle 2” were originally meant to be played by the lander once it reached Mars, but the lander unfortunately went missing for 12 years. Although the lander was thought to be found, it is, unfortunately, unknown whether or not the track actually played once it had reached Mars.

songs.title: Beetlebum

description.plain:
“Beetlebum” is a song by English alternative rock band Blur. It was released as the lead single for the band’s eponymous fifth album, Blur. The single became Blur’s second to reach the number one spot in the UK Singles Chart (after “Country House”)

Damon Albarn has confessed that the song is about heroin and the drug experiences he had with his then-girlfriend, Justine Frischmann of Elastica. In the 2010 Blur documentary, No Distance Left to Run, Albarn confirmed this notion on film. The song’s title is a reference to the phrase “Chasing the beetle” which refers to inhaling the smoke from heated heroin, morphine, or opium that has been placed on a piece of tin-foil. Albarn has stated in an interview with MTV that the song describes a complicated emotion, sort of ‘sleepy’ and sort of ‘sexy’.

songs.title: Berserk

description.plain:
Developing his admiration for Syd Barrett, Graham Coxon instigated this 6:50 instrumental freakout that combines elements of four songs (“No Good Trying”, “No Man’s Land”, “Baby Lemonade”, and “Late Night”) from Barrett’s two solo LP’s of late 1970.

Reactions to the track were mixed. “This is what Graham’s solo album will sound like,” says Alex James. “Not worth dwelling on,” says Andy Ross. Indisputably the most unhinged of the early Blur recordings.

– information courtesy of Select Magazine’s 1995 “Blur – How Did They Do That?” feature

songs.title: B.L.U.R.E.M.I.

description.plain:
“B.L.U.R.E.M.I.” appears to be a comment about genericness in popular music. The title of the song is a combination of Blur and EMI, the label the band were signed onto and one of the big four record companies at the time.

This can be seen in the heavily processed and repetitive vocals, especially the chorus, which sounds as if the band has been squeezed out of a sound machine.

Everything about the album sounds desperate and chaotic. B.L.U.R.E.M.I. is the squally end to old Blur.
-Graham Coxon, 13 Special Edition

songs.title: Brothers and Sisters

description.plain:
Brothers And Sisters, was apparently was one of the last tracks added to the album. The song’s lyrics focus on drugs, and was supposedly inspired by the list of 28 drugs that former US President John F Kennedy took to keep him functioning. They state that people have become too dependant on drugs and manufactured chemicals, and that instead of relying on them people should refrain from their use and ‘rebuild your lives’.

Musically the song starts off with some Middle Eastern sounding guitar, before settling into a catchy groove reminiscent of the previous track. Dave delivers some more solid drumming and Alex gives us perhaps the best bass line we’ve seen so far on the album. Damon’s guitar work is also effective and fits well with the other musical elements of the song.

songs.title: Charmless Man

description.plain:
The fourth and final single from The Great Escape, described by Damon Albarn as, “the end of something… it was the end of British pop. For us, anyway”. It is supposedly about Suede frontman Brett Anderson, who used to date Albarn’s then-girlfriend, Justine Frischmann, and with whom Albarn had a rivalry with in the ‘90s.

The song’s title is a nod to “This Charming Man” by British alternative rock pioneers The Smiths.

body.plain: “Chemical World” is the seventh track off of Blur’s 1993 album “Modern Life is Rubbish”. It topped at 28 on the UK singles Chart.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
The pay-me girl has had enough of the bleeps
So she takes the bus into the country
Although she got herself rosy cheeks
She didn't leave enough money to pay the rent
The landlord says that she's out in a week
What a shame, she was just getting comfy
Now she's eating chocolate to induce sleep
And in a chemical world, it's very, very, very cheap

[Chorus]
And I don't know about you
But they're putting the holes in, yes, yes
It's been a hell of a do
They've been putting the holes in, yes, yes

[Verse 2]
Peeping Thomas has a very nice view
Across the street at the exhibitionist
These townies, they never speak to you
Just stick together so they never get lonely
Feeling lead, feeling quite light-headed
Had to sit down and have some sugary tea
In a chemical world, in a chemical world
It's very, very, very cheap
[Chorus]
And I don't know about you
But they're putting the holes in, yes, yes
It's been a hell of a do
They've been putting the holes in, yes, yes, yes

[Instrumental break]

[Chorus]
I don't know about you
But they're putting the holes in, yes, yes
It's been a hell of a do
They've been putting the holes in, yes, yes
And now she's right out of view
They've been putting the holes in, yes, yes
Well, I don't know about you
They've been putting the holes in, yes, yes

[Outro]
Until you can see right through
Until you can see right through
Until you can see right through3EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: Clover Over Dover

description.plain:
This touching number about suicide is actually inspired by the crude rhyme Roll Me Over In The Clover. For a long time, “Clover Over Dover” also held the distinction of being the only song from Parklife to have never been played live.

However, on March 29, 2019, nearly 25 years since its release, the band finally played the song live during Damon Albarn’s Africa Express gig.

songs.title: Coffee & TV

description.plain: “Coffee & TV” is a song by the British alternative rock band Blur. The verses are sung by the band’s guitarist, Graham Coxon, who also wrote the lyrics. Its musical style is an anomaly in comparison with the rest of 13, and is similar to Blur’s earlier, Britpop days, despite featuring heavy guitar distortion and feedback during the instrumental break, major characteristics of 13.

songs.title: Commercial Break

description.plain:
“Commercial Break” is an instrumental hidden track that appears a few seconds after “Resigned” ends. It is also the shortest track on the album, lasting only 56 seconds.

 The track starts off with a soft guitar-driven melody reminiscent of music played at carnivals or funfair rides, before delving into a faster punk-like part.

songs.title: Country House

description.plain:
This song, Blur’s first number-one single, reached the top of the charts after the “Battle of Britpop” one of the most renowned music rivalries of the 90’s – Blur vs Oasis- culminated in “Country House” and “Roll with It” being released in the same week.

The music video was directed by Britain’s most successful living artist, Damien Hirst.

In the 1990s, Hirst’s relationship with collector and gallery magnate Charles Saatchi brought him fame. He is mostly known for his gruesome abstract works centering around the theme of death, most of which involve the display of dead animals in various bizarre states of dissection.



It also features comedian Matt Lucas, then of Shooting Stars fame.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ipmIYF0F4QA

songs.title: Crazy Beat

description.plain: “Crazy Beat” was compared to Song 2 from the band’s self-titled album. XFM described the song as “Fatboy Slim meets Middle Eastern Punk rock … energetic, punked-out rocker. But as much as this song might appeal to the neo-DIY set—complete with its jumpy chorus and lively melody—Blur are anything but. If there’s one thing Blur are known for, it’s lots and lots and lots of production. Norman Cook (aka Fatboy Slim), builds this number with tons of sound, so there’s always another active level to uncover.” According to Albarn, the song “started off in such a different way. The nearest thing I could compare it to is a really bad version of Daft Punk. So, we got sick of it and then put in that descending guitar line over it to rough it up a bit.” He also stated “It had this sort of mad vocoder-ish vocal and the melody was over a real sort of skanky groove and just this almost descending semi tonal guitar. The melody worked over it and it was amazing coz it shouldn’t have worked, another little magic moment for us.”

songs.title: Dan Abnormal

description.plain:
A song from The Great Escape that sums up much of the album – normal people, lonely people, conformity, and culture.

Unlike the previous records in the ‘Life Trilogy,’ The Great Escape was focused more on Damon’s own relationship with those broad themes. “Dan Abnormal”, an anagram for Damon Albarn, is about the lead singer and britpop icon.

Damon Albarn gets bored, goes out on Fridays, watches the tele, eats shit food, and dreams about lasses… he’s as much as anyone else as they all are.

songs.title: Dancehall

description.plain:
Contains a sample of the 1967 song “Suzy Creamcheese” by Teddy and His Patches – one of the few Blur tracks that directly samples another song.

The track appeared on CD2 of the “Beetlebum” single release, and as the 19th track on the deluxe edition of Blur’s self-titled album.

It is also featured as a hidden track between “Essex Dogs” and “Interlude” on US releases of the album, starting several seconds after Essex Dogs ends (around 6:24).

songs.full_title: Death of a Party by Blur
songs.title: Death of a Party

description.plain:
“Death of a Party” is the eighth track off of Blur’s 1997 self-titled album. It is about STI’s (specifically AIDS), and the people who have “died” or have had their lives ruined due to these infections and illnesses.

 Although the take that would make it on the album was recorded in 1996, the song dates back all the way to 1992, when the band had recorded a drastically different acoustic demo of the song, which the band would release in 1996 as a fan-club only release.

songs.title: Don’t Bomb When You’re the Bomb
songs.title_with_featured: Don't Bomb When You're the Bomb

description.plain:
The largely electronic piece was recorded towards the start of the sessions for Think Tank.

The track was inspired by the Iraq conflict hence the Arabic text on the red labels. It is one of the band’s rarer promotional singles, along with “The Wassailing Song”, “Death of a Party” and “Bugman”.

According to Damon Albarn, when a box of these vinyls were going through customs, one of the boxes was labeled “bomb”. This led to the boxes being handed over to the police and being destroyed in a controlled explosion.

The track was included in the band’s Blur 21 box set in 2012.

According to Damon Albarn, when a box of these vinyls were going through customs, one of the boxes was labeled “bomb”. This led to the boxes being handed over to the police and being destroyed in a controlled explosion.

The track was included in the band’s Blur 21 box set in 2012.

songs.title: Down

description.plain:
Perhaps the first song written by Blur – as opposed to Seymour. It was a conscious attempt to move on from Seymour’s lunatic diversity and be a rock song of its time. Damon, while a fan of Julian Cope, knew little of current trends. Graham, however, was immersed in the abstract guitar soundscapes found on My Bloody Valentine’s 1988 LP Isn’t Anything. “But I was very crude and simplistic at the time,” he adds.

Nonetheless, the influence of MBV and other indie luminaries of the day can be heard in “Down”’s frazzled languor. Assessments of the song’s worth differ. Andy Ross feels that “"Down" is a really good song but it belongs to another incarnation.” Less charitably, Alex sees it as “all over the place.”

– information courtesy of Select Magazine’s 1995 “Blur – How Did They Do That?” feature

description.plain:
Fourteenth song on Blur’s self-titled. The song talks about the people of Essex. Damon Albarn spent most of his childhood in Aldham, Essex.  He described the place as:

One of those burgeoning Thatcher experiments where they were building loads of small estates.
-Damon Albarn

songs.title: Explain

description.plain: “Explain”, an old Seymour song written during the manic nights at the Beat Factory, reflects one of the band’s then obsession with the Pixies. The band always referred to the song as “Can’t Explain”, the title of The Who’s first single from 1965. The song still commands the band’s affection. As Damon points out, “We didn’t want to get rid of Seymour songs because they were part of what we were.” “Explain” was recorded with Stephen Street during the same May ’91 session at Maison Rouge that produced “High Cool”.

songs.title: For Tomorrow

description.plain:
A new sound for Blur, who were finally coming in to their own, “For Tomorrow” was the lead single from Modern Life is Rubbish, their second album and the one which ushered in their trademark Britpop sound that they would become known for over their next three albums.

It reached #28 in the UK Singles Chart and was the only song from Modern Life is Rubbish to appear in the band’s Best Of compilation.

songs.title: French Song

description.plain:
French Song is the first track on the second disc of the special edition of 13, and appears as a b-side on CD2 of UK releases of “Tender”, along with Japan CD releases.

  The song is completely instrumental, and gets faster over time and alternating between roughly 6 different riffs, until it reaches the climax and it plays static until the end.

songs.title: Ghost Ship

description.plain:
From the Rolling Stone review of Magic Whip:
The Magic Whip is named after a Chinese brand of firecracker, and Blur recorded the guts of its 12 songs with explosive impulse in Hong Kong after a big Far East gig was canceled. Albarn — Blur’s lyricist, whose solo work and collaborations draw liberally from Asia and Africa — drops local references in the gauzy drift of “Ghost Ship” (“Swinging on a cable/Up to Po Lin,” a Buddhist monastery)

songs.title: Girls & Boys

description.plain:
Peaking a #5 in the UK charts and considered a comeback hit in its day after poor sales of Blur’s second album Modern Life Is Rubbish. It was named song of the year 1994 by NME and Melody Maker magazines.

The single’s cover art was taken from a condom wrapper, reflecting the song’s focus on sexual promiscuity on summer holidays in Europe. The music has a convergence of various pop and dance styles, summed up by bassist Alex James as “Disco drums, nasty guitars and Duran Duran bass", with the first being done by a drum machine.

songs.title: Good Song

description.plain: Good Song is the fourth track in Think Tank. In October 2003, the song was released as the third and final single from that album, peaking at #22 in the UK Singles Chart. The single was Blur’s lowest placing single since 1993’s “Sunday Sunday”, ending the bands consecutive run of Top 20 singles.

songs.title: Go Out

description.plain:
Graham explained to NME why this was chosen as the first single from the new album:

It wasn’t a jolly, winking, overfamiliar Blur thing. I realize that a lot of people love below because of those songs, and lots of people hate them because of it, and people from the camp who hate us probably don’t know much about the other stuff that we did. “Go Out” struck me as being somewhere between the two – it’s sort of casual sounding, but it’s also quite powerful. For me, it felt like a place that we hadn’t really done before: it’s mildly familiar because of Damon’s voice, but sonically is quite different from anything we’ve done before."

如何自制冰淇淋

土鸡蛋蛋黄4个
细砂糖100克（3又1/2盎司）
玉米粉一茶匙（也可以省略不加）
高脂（48%脂肪）鲜奶油300毫升（1/2品脱）
全脂牛奶300毫升（1/2品脱）
1支香草豆荚

先确认你冰箱的冷冻库有足够空间存放冰淇淋。
首先，鸡蛋的蛋白和蛋黄分开，取蛋黄部分放入一个大的碗里。
（此份食谱，你将不需要蛋白，你可以用蛋白来做法式蛋白糖霜脆饼。）
将细砂糖倒入蛋黄液中，并使用打蛋器将颜色打至泛白浓稠。
并使用打蛋器将颜色打至泛白浓稠。
若有需要加入玉米粉，
可在此时加入作法（2）的混合液并搅拌均匀。

[Chorus 1]
To the local
To the lo-o-o, I go out
To the lo-o-o-o-ocal by myself
To the lo-o-o-o-ocal
将香草荚直直剖开，用刀背刮出香草荚，
然后把香草籽加入鲜奶油和牛奶的混合液。
取一中锅，将鲜奶油和牛奶放入。
取一中锅，将鲜奶油和牛奶放入。
加热做法（5）的混合液直到将要沸腾前熄火，
缓缓将加热后的混合液倒入做法
（3）的蛋黄和砂糖搅拌均匀。

[Chorus 2]
He going to the local
He going to the local-o-ohh
He going to the lo-o-o-o-ocal
He going to the lo-o-o-o-ocal

将加热过后的奶黄，用滤网过筛到一个干净的锅子，以小火慢加热。
同时用一只木汤匙，一边不停地搅拌。搅拌时要特别注意锅边以免沾着，直到奶黄变热并呈浓稠状，
且可以用木汤匙背面在奶黄表面划出清楚一条线的程度时，即可离火。这个过程大约要十分钟。
将奶黄放入一个大，浅且可置于冷冻库的容器，
让它待凉至室温（你也可以将容器放置于冰块水中），
加速降温速度。
当奶黄降温至室温，把容器盖上盖子，将它放入冰箱冷藏室至隔夜。
隔天再将奶黄移入冰冻库放置三小时。记得每小时拿出来一次，用电动打蛋器搅拌。

[Chorus 3]
She does it with herself
She does it with herself
She does it on her o-o-o-o-o-own
She does it on her o-o-o-o-o-own
享受！！！EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: Ice Cream Man

description.plain:
A spectre haunts Blur’s new album, “The Magic Whip” — the spectre of communism.

Having Hong Kong as a source of inspiration meant that at some point the skeletons of China’s repressive past would have to be dusted off and brought to light, and “Ice Cream Man” is the first song in The Magic Whip to address this topic.

Of course, to frame a song about bureaucratic suppression of the human spirit and State-sanctioned six-figure death tolls in a 4-minute whistle-able pop song would be a delicate act to say the least. Perhaps, sensing this, Damon Albarn opted to not go all-out lyrically in this one. He provides glimpses and suggestions, but doesn’t dwell too long in what he shows. Instead of an angry indictment, this song is more like a somewhat numbed lament. The result is not as strident as the subject matter would dictate in a less frivolous context, but the final effect is still strong. The song artfully encapsulates a grim subject in a sugar-coated wrapping, and the contrast makes it appropriately chilling.

songs.title: I Know (Extended Mix)

description.plain:
Recorded in the same session as “She’s So High”, this Seymour-era song was briefly considered as a possible A-side. It’s easy to see why. Unlike its introspective flipside, “I Know” is a bare-faced ‘indie dance’ production number (especially the extended version on the 12-inch and the CD.) Self-consciously trippy, it clutches the coat-tails of 1990’s biggest music phenomenon – the shuffling dance beats of Manchester. Graham now acknowledges, “Obviously, we used that [beat] as a stepping stone to getting noticed.”

Despite its pleasant harmony vocals, the song is vapid, of note chiefly to those who cannot get enough backwards guitar. A keen fan of Syd Barrett’s Pink Floyd, Graham’s versatility as a guitarist was important in Blur’s shift from Seymour’s ragged punk towards a more psychedelic sound. For the next year, Damon’s lyrics would skirt lethargy and melancholia in increasingly banal ways, selling the group’s musicality short and also implying that Blur had nothing in their heads except radio silence.

– information courtesy of Select Magazine’s 1995 “Blur – How Did They Do That?” feature

songs.title: I’m All Over

description.plain:
A song from the Blur live set of early 1990, “I’m All Over” is a short (1:57) but endearing sprint on the subject of detachment, with Graham’s voice harmonising loosely on the choruses with Damon’s rather in style of early R.E.M.. The inspiration for Dave’s spluttering, jerking drum-and-cymbal pattern was “Where Are You Baby?” by Betty Boo, which Graham instructed him to copy. Graham takes little pride in this, calling “I’m All Over” “a ridiculous song with a terrible, synthetic drumbeat.”

– information courtesy of Select Magazine’s 1995 “Blur – How Did They Do That?” feature

songs.title: I’m Fine

description.plain:
A cheesy Seymour-era tune recorded during the same sessions as “Sing”, Blur had grown tired of the track by the mid-90s, not at least for its breezily inane sentiments which Alex James had characterised as “a little Jason Donovan”. This passable ’60s pastiche sports McCartney-esque bass and a Townshend-style main riff. Graham Coxon had just acquired a new 12-string guitar, hence its prominence.

– information courtesy of Select Magazine’s 1995 “Blur – How Did They Do That?” feature

songs.title: Inertia

description.plain: Inertia shows how Blur experimented with their styles from the very first album. Exploring rich shoegaze-style guitars and fuzz effects, Inertia is a perfect title. Defined as the resistance to change, inertia lets you bask in a slow, repetitive melody; almost lulling the listener to sleep.

songs.title: Intermission

description.plain:
This interlude from Modern Life Is Rubbish begins as a simple, innocuous piano riff that slowly escalates into a blisteringly fast and frantic instrumental with drums and guitar.

The song was used in Baby Driver, during a scene in which Baby waits for his crew to return from a potentially dangerous heist…increasing tension in much the same way as “Zorba the Greek” in Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels.

The song was used in Baby Driver, during a scene in which Baby waits for his crew to return from a potentially dangerous heist…increasing tension in much the same way as “Zorba the Greek” in Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels.

songs.full_title: Jawbone (Black Book Alternate Version) by Blur
songs.title: Jawbone (Black Book Alternate Version)

description.plain:
“Jawbone” is a demo to “Black Book”, the song later taking on the latter name becoming the B-side to “Music is my Radar”.

“Jawbone” is largely different than it’s B-side version, the first half being significantly softer with a prominent distorted bassline and a vaguely African-sounding percussion starting a roughly minute in, foreshadowing the general style of Think Tank. In addition to this, the loud section of the song is significantly noisier, with the lyrics being almost hauntingly half-yelled (rather than sung in falsetto as in the B-side version), resting atop a noisy distorted droning guitar playing under an even noisier lead. The song’s outro is also largely devoid of electronics, which are present in the completed B-side version.
 The song also fades out at the 5:30 mark, making it 3 minutes shorter than it’s B-side version in addition to a drastically different ending.

songs.title: Lonesome Street

description.plain:
“Lonesome Street” is the third single from Blur’s album The Magic Whip.

Describing the track to NME, Graham explained:

There’s a definite familiarity with that song. We weren’t in uncharted waters with it, we were well within the realms of the Blur world. It’s got that cheeky-sounding vocal of Damon’s, that perverse nursery-rhyme feel, and it all sounds a bit like you’re careening through a night of chaos. When I was listening back to it with Stephen, I thought, ‘Why not go the whole hog and have a really Syd Barrett-y middle-eight in there?‘ So I wrote another section for it, which is about the way you seem to ride the tarmac in Hong Kong: you stand on the road, you don’t move, and it’ll take you anywhere you want to go. It’s a very lighthearted way to start the record."

The music video was released on Blur’s YouTube channel on April 2nd, 2015 and it was directed by Ben Reed.

songs.title: Look Inside America

description.plain:
Blur’s relationship with the United States was always… interesting. Modern Life is Rubbish, their unabashedly British second album (and one of the starting points of britpop), was reportedly written out of the band’s dislike for the grunge wave sweeping the world at the time, and the desire to bring British music to the forefront of pop culture again.

The band’s britpop-era albums have several songs referencing the U.S.A., namely “Miss America” and “Magic America”. While both of those are sarcastic in tone and critical of American values, “Look Inside America” is the tale of Blur finally coming to terms with the country and admitting, after all, that ‘she’s alright’.

songs.title: Mellow Song

description.plain: “Mellow Song” is the eight track on Blur’s 1999 album “13.” The title suits the song very well, since throughout most of the song the usual abrasiveness and noise that most of the record embraced is nowhere to be found. It turns it up a notch towards the end of the song, but for 13 this is a pretty mellow song.

songs.full_title: Me, White Noise by Blur (Ft. Phil Daniels)
songs.title: Me, White Noise

description.plain:
“Me, White Noise” is a hidden track from Blur’s seventh studio album, Think Tank, located in the pre-gap of the CD, which could originally only be accessed by playing track one and rewinding.

Three versions of the song exist: the version that appears on the album, featuring actor Phil Daniels, who previously featured in “Parklife” in 1994; one which has Damon Albarn delivering the vocals, with completely different lyrics; and a live version which was given away for free with the Observer newspaper.

description.plain: A mirrorball is defined as “a revolving ball covered with small mirrored facets, used to provide lighting effects at discos or dances.”, and is colloquially known as a disco ball. This song is set in Hong Kong, as there are many place names from the area and the entire album was recorded there, sue to the cancellation of a large gig.

songs.title: Miss America

description.plain:
Blur made a name for itself as a Brit-pop group, but much of their following is owed not only to the stylistic diversity of their records, but also how relatable their songs are.

Damon Albarn, an outspoken critic of celebrity culture, has an uncanny talent for imagining figurative characters.  On “Miss America”, he makes a criticism on the commodification of beauty.  Miss America herself wears a label and is an artificial champion for American women, especially because modern life is rubbish.

songs.title: M.O.R.

description.plain: The fourth and final single from Blur, “M.O.R.” gained inspiration from two songs by David Bowie and Brian Eno, “Boys Keep Swinging” and “Fantastic Voyage”. The two songs were an experiment with the same chord progression, and “M.O.R.” continues that experiment. In particular, the chorus is heavily inspired by the call-and-response chorus from “Boys Keep Swinging”.

songs.title: M.O.R. (Road Version)

description.plain:
“M.O.R. (Road Version)” was released as the 24th track on the Deluxe version of Blur, and was used in the song’s music video. The “Road Version” was also the version used for the US CD single.

 The road version of “M.O.R.” is significantly different, a more rougher and “punkier” sound than it’s album version, as well as several minor lyric changes. In addition to this, the intro and verse riffs are slightly different, as well as the post-chorus riff being drastically different. The road version of “M.O.R.” also bears a yelled outro, never featured in the album version of the song.

songs.title: Mr. Briggs

description.plain:
“"Mr. Briggs” is the band’s first song to tell a story. The apathetic Briggs is based on a Liverpudlian Damon encountered in early 1990 while living in a Greenwich bedsit. Dismissed as “a crappy Pink Floyd demo” by Graham’s girlfriend of the time, ‘Mr. Briggs’ is not too far removed, thematically, from Pink Floyd’s ‘character’ songs such as “Arnold Layne” and “Corporal Clegg”", and a Barrett-esque note is struck with the humdrum lyrics: “He has a three-bar heater but it don’t keep him warm/If he bought another, then he’d have three more.” Graham’s three guitar tracks show the triple-pronged range of 1990 Blur: dexterous, bluesy chording; MBV-esque shrieking; and random, punky mischief.
– information courtesy of Select Magazine’s 1995

“Blur – How Did They Do That?” feature

songs.title: Mr. Robinson’s Quango

description.plain:
Track 8 on The Great Escape, “Mr. Robinson’s Quango” was the first song recorded for the album – live performances date back as early as September 1994, less than six month’s after Parklife’s release.

The song’s a pretty obvious crack at rich right-wing bureaucrats.

songs.title: New World Towers

description.plain:
This dark, melancholy song is the second song on Blur’s 2015 album The Magic Whip.

A interview claims Damon walked past the entrance to New World Towers in Hong Kong right when he needed a four-syllable title for his song about modern-day loneliness.
